patient_information: A 64-year-old Japanese man with a medical history of hypertension and right cerebellar infarction. Recent simple partial seizures were well controlled by an antiepileptic agent.
chief_complaint: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures followed by weakness of the right lower extremity.
history_of_present_illness: The patient was admitted due to generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Prior to this, recent simple partial seizures had been well controlled by antiepileptic agents.
exposure_and_epidemiology: The probable infection route was through consumption of raw chicken meat, which the patient ate approximately once a month before the generalized seizure. Cerebral sparganosis cases are mainly reported from Asian countries, including Japan.
physical_exam: Neurological examination did not reveal any abnormality on admission (beyond the seizure-related weakness).
labs_and_diagnostics: Laboratory results showed no abnormalities, including no eosinophilia or leukocytosis. Head CT revealed a small high-density nodule with an enhanced perifocal low-density area in the left occipital lobe. MRI showed a ring-enhancing, tunnel-shaped lesion in the left occipital lobe (T1-weighted ring-shaped nodule with gadolinium enhancement, T2-weighted hyperintensity with adjacent ventricular dilation, post-contrast coronal and sagittal T1-weighted images demonstrated a tunnel-shaped enhancement, 'tunnel sign'). Angiography findings were normal except for right vertebral artery occlusion. Open surgery revealed a white, tape-like, live worm-like structure, measuring 1 to 3 mm in width and up to 12.5 cm in length at maximum extension with active movements, which was completely removed. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) results of serum and cerebrospinal fluid revealed strong positivity for Spirometra mansoni.
differential_diagnosis: Brain tumours or metastases, neurocysticercosis, cerebral schistosomiasis, paragonimiasis. Also considered are cerebral toxoplasmosis, cerebral cryptococcomas, and tuberculomas (especially in immunocompromised patients), and HIV test for unclear CNS lesions.
management_and_clinical_course: Open surgery with craniotomy was performed for complete removal of the live worm-like structure. After surgical removal of the worm, the patient was well without seizures at the most recent examination.
final_diagnosis: Cerebral Sparganosis, confirmed by surgical removal and identification of the sparganum, and strong positivity for Spirometra mansoni via ELISA.
